This Company's system of submarine telegraph

communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY
div.p: A few days ago we published a review of the interesting article on the palms of Egypt, which has been contributed to the Bulletin of the Alexandria Horticultural Society by M. A d'Abaza The Bulletin contains two other very valuable contributions, of which "Some Hints on Rose-growing in Egypt" is a practical guide to the cultivation of the queen of flowers by one who is the acknowledged British "facile princeps" of the art in this country — the Anglo-Egyptian Dean Hole Every word, therefore, from him on this subject is sure to be read with the deepest attention. Dr. Keatinge who, some years ago, gave Alexandrians a much appreciated lecture on rose growing, modestly deprecates any idea of a claim on his part to originality in his 'hints," most of which he assures us have been culled from the "Boot of the Rose" (by the late Rev. A. Foster Melliar of which he strongly advises the purchase. The sixteen pages of his paper contain valuable hints on every branch of Egyptian rose cultivation, ending with a most useful list of 18 hybrid roses, 29 tea roses and 12 climbing varieties, which Dr Keatinge's personal experience has proved will do, Well in this country.

The last 18 pages of the Bulletin consist of "Leaves from a Note Book" by Judge Sanders, the vice-president of the committee of the A. H. S., whose reputation as a practical horticulturist and the successful organizer of our Alexandria flower shows, from their commence­ment, has long been established. The "Leaves" contain a large amount of interesting historical information on the subject of Egyptian cultivated plants, from various sources, commencing with a resume of what is known concerning the "Papyrus," its gradual extinction, and reintroduction of late years. The "Jacaranda," mentioned as one of the trees intro­duced under Mehemet Ali (1803-1847), is ignored by Delchevalerie in his "Etudes Egyptiennes" (l870) describing all the gardens of Cairo and Alexandria except the one at Alexandria in which the solitary Jacaranda in Egypt existed; nor did he include it in the list of seeds and flowers of all the ornamental trees in Egypt shewn by him at the Vienna Interna­tional exhibition in 1873.

The above garden, now belonging to the Jesuit College, but formerly known as Beit Thurburn from its proprietor 80 years ago, was rented by General Sir E. Stanton when Consul General (1866-1876), and the Jacaranda may have been planted during his tenure. It was still a very fine tree in 1885, but has since disappeared, being a rapid grower but very short-lived ; Delchevalerie mentions the bee for the first time in his "Apercu General," written for the "Societe d'acclimatation de France" (1881), as flowering and fruiting well in "le jardin de Torborn a Alexandrie" whence it had, by that time, spread over the Delta and been some years in the gardens of Ghizeh, Ghezireh and the Ezbekieh in Cairo The "Jacaranda mimosifolia" (J. Ovalifolia) was introduced to British cultivation from Brazil in 1818 as a stove plant.

It is curious that the English name "potato" for the "Solanum tuberosum," brought by Thomas Harriot (1560-1621), the mathema­tical tutor of Sir W. Raleigh, from Virginia in 1585 (where it seems to have been imported from S. America), should be a corruption of the American name for the "Sweet Potato" (Batatas edulis), a plant of the "convolvulus" family said by von Humboldt to have been brought to Spain by Christopher Columbus 92 years before Virginia was christened ; and again, in 1519, when Pigafetta introduced it from Brazil ; the Batatas was cultivated in Eng and long before the common potato, and the two plants, of such diverse botanical classification, were frequently confounded in contemporary accounts. The potato has long been known in Spanish S. America as "Papas" and the sweet potato as "Batatas."

The view of our great lexicographer, cited by Judge Sandars, that "if he was a rich man he would propagate all kinds of trees that grow in the open air," rather than such as require the shelter of glass, is one that we cordially endorse, especially as applied to the climate of Egypt, for which we have such vast store of beautiful flowering shrubs and herbaceous perennials to draw upon, from similar latitudes in both hemispheres, as com­pared with the possibilities of acclimatisation in Great Britain. We earnestly hope that, under its new financial conditions, the A.H.S. will not confine its efforts entirely to the utilitarian side of horticulture, and will soon gladden our eyes with the sight of some ornamental novelties; for beautiful as our

Flamboyants, Jacarandas, Tecomas, Poinset- tias, and Oleanders are in our Alexandria gardens, we are tired of seeing the same trees, shrubs and creepers in all of them, and long for some of the many equally hardy flowering and foliage beauties, only waiting to be transferred from their native subtro­pical homes in China, Japan, North and South America, the East and West Indies, Australia, and South Africa to the cosmo­politan land of Egypt.

It is understood that an Irish Devolution

Bill will be presented as a provisional experi­ment and the arrangements for the constitu­tion of the Irish Council will be left open for enlargement for 10 years' time. It is expected that the Irish Commoners will be ipso facto members of the new Council. The success of the experiment will depend upon the Council's disposal of the money scorning from savings under the Imperial administration. (Reuter}

The Senate adopted the amended Immigration Bill without a division. Consequently the difficulty with Japan has been settled, the Californians having agreed to admit Japanese children to the schools attended by whites immediately the bill was passed. (Reuter)

The Minister of the Coloniesdeclares that the contract between the British and French railway companies for an extension to Addis- Abeba is a violation of the Convention of 1902, though it was possible that the contract would ultimately be sanctioned. (Reuter)
The agreement for the construction of the Laokai Yunnansen railway has been signed here by the representatives of the Government and the Indo-Chinese Railway Company. (R.)
Princess Marie Clementine, mother of Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria, is dead. (R.)
The Archduchess Clementine of Coburg is dead. (Havas)
Owing to the death of Carducci, which recurred yesterday, mourning is general through- Italy. (Havas)
The suburbs beginning from the villa inundated. Several native families have pe- rished. The damages exceed a million (francs)
■ Havas}

A great political demonstration took place here last night. Sir G Farrar declared that the Progressives were fighting for God and the King against oligarchy and the autocracy, and they must work for the establishment of a British South Africa and to eliminate Downing Street influence. (Reuter)

div.head: DELTA LAND CO. LTD.
div.p: IMPORTANT DECISIONS.

We are authorised by the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company to state that a meeting of the directors held on Saturday confirmed the resolution arrived at by the Delta Light Railway Company's Board to re-affiliate the two companies on the original terms on which the Delta Land Company was formed. This decision must, of course, be confirmed by general meeting of the shareholders.

Farther, the London Board of the Delta Land Company having carefully considered the question as to whether the company's business could be administered from London or Egypt, are convinced that in the best interests of the shareholders the administration should be in Egypt and, as a very large majority of the shareholders are resident in Egypt, their convenience would be better studied if general meetings were held in Egypt. Taking these matters into consideration the London Board has generously come to the conclusion that they would best serve the interests of the shareholders by resigning. They have therefore elected the following gentlemen to replace them, viz.. Mr. P. W. Carver of Alexandria, Maurice Cattaui Bey of Cairo,Capt. A. Adams, R E , general manager of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways. These three gentlemen, together with Baron Jacques de Menasce and Mr. J. W Williamson, will form the new board of the Delta Land Co. and it will be farther strengthened by the addition of a mem-her of the firm of Messrs. Snares of Cairo as soon as certain negotiations now pending be-tween the company and Messrs. Snares are completed.

We are pleased to hear that the new Board of the Delta Land Co. have made very strong representations to Sir Auckland Colvin, K C S.I, K.C.M.G., C.I.E, to remain honorary president of the company. Sir Auckland has not yet definitely accepted but we feel confident we are voicing the wishes of the shareholders in begging of him to give a favourable answer to this request, for the able and generous manner in which he has brought to an amicable solution the outstanding differences between the London and local Boards of the company has endeared him to the shareholders, who feel that with Sir Auckland Colvin as honorary president of their company they would not be severing their connection with him,

div.head: Alexandria's New Hotel.
div.p: The inauguration of the Savoy Palace Hotel in Rosetta-avenue will take place on Saturday, 23rd inst., when a grand reception will be held in the afternoon.

div.head: Savoy Ball.
div.p: We may remind our readers that the Savoy fancy dress ball takes place on Tuesday next. Persons not wearing a fancy dress will have to pay a fine of P.T. 40 for charity.

div.head: Mena House Hotel.
div.p: The great fancy dress ball at Mena House takes place on Wednesday next at 9.30 p.m. Guests not wearing fancy dress will pay a fine of P.T. 20, the proceeds of which will go to charity.

div.head: Plague at Jeddah.
div.p: The Delegate of the Quarantine Board in the Hedjz telegraphs that five deaths from plague took place on the 15th inst. at Jeddah. The deaths up to date number 50. The general state of health is unsatisfactory.

div.head: The Khedivial Ball.
div.p: Over two thousaud invitations have been issued for the Khedivial Ball which is to be held at Abdeen Palace on the 28th inst., and further invitations are being issued. This year's ball is expected to eclipse any that has ever bean held at Abdesn Palace.

div.head: Societe Internationale des Employes."
div.p: A benefit performance will be given at the Zizinia Theatre on Wednesday next, 20th just., on behalf of the "Société Internationale des Employes d'Alexandrie," when "La Dannazione di Fanst" will be given. Almost all the seats have been taken for the occasion.

div.head: M. Zervudachi's Cold Mine.
div.p: Mr. George Zervudachi, of Alexandria, has purchased an Abyssinian gold mine from a Russian. On Saturday last an expedition left Alexandria for Abyssinia consisting of the engineering expert, M. Carafan, two French mining experts, and a number of workmen, in order to work the mine.

div.head: Reception for Americans.
div.p: Mr. Iddings, the American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, and Mrs. Iddings will be "at home" at the Agency. No. 5, Scha warbi Pasha street Cairo, on Friday next, 22nd inst., Washington's birthday, and will be glad to receive any of their compatriots who are in Cairo on that day, and who may do them the honour to call between 4 and 6 o'clock.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE'S RETURN.
div.p: The Khedive is expected to arrive at Montozah tomorrow on his return from the Siwa Oasis. His Highness will proceed to Cairo on Wednesday evening.
H.H. the Khedivah came down to Alexandria on Saturday from Cairo in order to meet the Khedive on his arrival from the desert.

div.head: DEATH OF KHEDIVIAL PRINCE.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Prince Ahmed Kamel Pasha, uncle of the Khedive, which took place at Cairo on Saturday at midnight. The funeral took place yesterday afternoon.
The late Prince, it is said, left an estate of the value of over L.E. 3,000,000. This has been bequeathed to his son Prince Youssef.

div.head: TODAY'S PROSPECTUSES.
div.p: We beg to draw the attention of our readers to the three interesting prospectuses which we publish in another part of to day's issue. "Levico Limited" is the conversion of the well-known and respected Alexandrian firm of Messrs V. Levi and Company into an English limited liability company. "La Barque d'Escompte et de Reports" is a new bank, which will no doubt attract the serious attention of the investing public. The Nile Transport Company will fill a need in catering for the ever increasing development of Nilotic navigation.
Another issue, which we announce to day, is that of the Express Nile Steamers Limited. The fall details of this new issue will be found in the next paragraph.

div.head: THE EXPRESS NILE COMPANY.
div.p: Les souscripteurs ordinaires, le cours actuel du titre étant de plus de £6 1/2 et promettant d atteindre à bref délai on prix beaucoup plus éievé. L'on s'attend eu effet généralement, an cours de £ 8 d'ici à quelques jours, ce qui fera entre le prix d'émission et la valeur réelle du titre une différene de £ 3.

Or, comme les porteurs d'actions anciennes auront droit à 2 actions nouvelles poor une ancienne, il en resultera pour eux un bénéfice d environ £ 6 qu'ils réaliseront en usant de leur droit de préférence et ce, en engageant pour toute mise de fonds la somme de £ 1 par action (c'est-à-dire P.T. 50 à la souscription et P.T. 50 à la répartition).

Voilà donc la question exposée au point de vue purement financier, mais l'affaire est, d'ailleurs, par elle-même excellente et d'un avenir brillant. Les résultats quelle a déjà donnés out été remarquablement satisfaisants ; on peut même dire qu'ils ont été réellement surprenants et ont dépassé toutes les espé­rances, car avec un premier capital minime, la Société a réussi en un court laps de temps, à organiser et a faire fonctionner un service de voyageurs et an service de marchandées qui marchent à souhait. Or, l'augmentation du capital social permettra de donner à ces deux branches an service des marchandises notam­ment, un développement appelé à donner des bénéfices considérables, en présence des avan­tages incontestables que le transport par la voie du Nil offre de plus en plus au commerce.

C'est, du reste, pour répondre spécialement à ces desiderata auxquels elle ne pouvait guère satisfaire avec un matériel insoffi-tant que la Société a résolu d'augmenter sa flottille, de manière à faire progressivement face à tontes les demandes de9 négociants.

Comme on le voit, l'entreprise est extrême­ment promettante. Elle répond à un besoin public qui s'aoon Itra avec l'extension que prendra nécessairement la navigation fl îviale en présence du développement croissant des » ff »ires.
Les souscriptions seront reçues chez MM. H de Vries et Boutigny, au Caire, où des bol letins sont mis à la disposition des sous cripteurs.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Philae arrived this morning from Glasgow, viâ Gibraltar and Malta, with general cargo.
The S. S. Bulgarian (Westcott and Laurance Lire) left Malta on Saturday morning, and i due here next Wednesday from Antwerp and London
Alexandria sporting club.—a sum of money was found last week in one of the dressing rooms of the Alexandria Sport- Club. Any member claiming this must □lease apply to the Clerk of the Course.

div.head: ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: Antiquaries Alarmed
PROTEST TO LORD CROMER.

Antiquaries of London has heard with tome surprise that a proposal is seriously entertained by the Egyptian Govern­ment to raise the level of the Nile dam at Assouan to the height originally proposed. The Society would point out that it is informed that such an alteration would, at high Nile, submerge the temples at Philae, and would result also in the flooding of a large area in Nubia undoubtedly containing many interest­ing sites. The Society feels bound to enter a protest against any scheme that would involve such a wholesale destruction of archæologîcal remains unless it be clearly demonstrated that the scheme is an absolute necessity for the well being of Egypt, and that the same bene­fits cannot be obtained in any other way. The Society feels the greater confidence in making the protest to the Egyptian Government in view of the important and costly works of con­servation that have already been carried out at Philae."

The prime mover in this agitation is Mr. Somers Clarke. This gentleman sent a letter to the Society of Antiquaries calling attention to a proposal to raise the dam at Assouan to the level originally suggested, despite the undertaking given in 1894 that it should not be carried higher than at present. Mr. Clarke recalled the disastrons effect such raining would entail both as regards the temples at Philae, and a large part of Nubia, which would be hopelessly drowned, and suggested that the Society should take action in the matter.

div.head: SAVOY DANCE.
div.p: "SAMSON ET DALILA."

What a contrast to last year's excellent performance ! It serves us right for grambling then. Mme. Chaix Bonheur saved the 2nd act by good acting and scientific use of a rather distasteful voice. M. Moisson was far but colourless ; M. Mézy voluminous and insccu- rate. The flower chorus was of course hope- less, and—here Mme. Chaix Bonheur and M. Mézy should have done better. The fine fugal duet and chorus at the end was badly sang. She was too slow and he too fast. The ballet pleased a good many people : certainly Mlle.

Saturday evening was so balmy and warm that the hall doors of the Savoy were opened wide and the dancers took fall advantage of the verandah between the dances, which were not finished till nearly half past one. The warmth of the ball room was quite excessive at times, and many people preferred to take their pleasure gently, though there were a few who clamoured for more even after the orchestra had left.

There were a good many strangers present on Saturday, and at one end of the room there was a bevy of some of the most beautiful frocks that have been seen this season. One especially attracted the notice of everyone : it was in white ont en princesse and had wide glittering lines of silver fall­ing from the bust to the hem, where there was a border of delicately painted roses. The same painted roses mingled with silver formed the sleeves and the decolletage, lines of thin filmy black outlining the fulness and being gathered into a big bow high at the back. Close by the wearer of this lovely frock was another in a dull deep shade of heliotrope with broad bands of dull silver lace on the skirt and corsage, the trimming the latter being continued over the shoul­ders and in a deep square across the back.

Lord and Lady Lanesborough were present, and Lady Newborough, who looked magnificent in a grey brocade, the bodice spark ling with jewels. The Countess of Hollnstein was also most handsomely attired and wore beautiful jewels. Lord and Lady Vivian were here, and Col. El Lewa aud Mrs. Watson were also among the dancers, the latter wearing a handsome pink silk dress trimmed with garlands of double stitched ruchings. Miss Blyth was with Capt. and Mrs. Rome ; and Mrs. and Miss Crofton were with Mrs. and Miss Carey and Miss Fox: Miss Crofton in blue embroidered with roses, Miss Carey wearing a lovely frock of white chiffon embroidered with marguerites and bordered with doll green panne, while the latter was in diamentée white. Mrs. Armstrong was in very handsome gown of white moire en- ornsted with heavy lace and bordered with large pompadour roses. Mrs. Mende's hand­some dress of blue was also adorned with pink roses, and one of her near neighbours had lovely panels of painted roses on her dress. Mrs. Stout was in a very pretty frock of fine lace, and Miss McKellar had on a delightful frock of black net trimmed with bands of velvet and lace and showing pointed vest and sleeves of white lace. Mrs Park Lyle was wearing a lovely bandeau o diamonds and turquoise across her hair, herf dress of soft satin bearing insertions of lace or net covered with ruchings and bands of satin.

Others present were Major and Mrs. Wynne, Miss Blythe, Mrs. and Miss Leverich, Mr. and Mrs. Packet, the Messrs and Miss de Bilinleki, Mr. and Miss Pooley, Miss Tuck, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish, Misses de Vahl, Mrs. and Miss Marron, Miss Nungovich, Mr. and Miss Allan Joseph, Miss Fearon, Miss Shaw, Mrs. and Miss de Wahn.

div.head: OPERA IN CAIRO.
KHEDIVIAL THEATRE.
"LOUISE."
div.p: A rather colourless performance except for the workroom scene, and the last act of all. Both these were well enough done : the "Batte. Montmartre" scene needed far more singing than M. Fontaine and Mlle. Charpentier could give.The orchestra was rather tame throughout. After all, "Lonise" is a disappointing opera. It has really original effects: the daybreak scene at Montmartre, the workroom, and the duet at Julien's house, followed by the entry of the masqueraders, are charming in conception and in execation. Poor M. Monteux ! really was amusing as the pape des fous, not the audience will only laugh at his voice every time he tries to sing. His acting is not so bad ; — this by the way. The scenes which might have been great are also charming—but no more. The duet, and the whole finale, that stirring "Paris m'appelle"—what an oppor­tunity for a really great composer who could have shown the soul of it all, love, revolt, con­vention, and the call of that great city tearing that convention to pieces, exacting worship and suffering of its sons and daughters !

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE.
"ERNÂNI."
div.p: The fine old filibustering sentiment of "Ernani" seemed to please the performers, and more especially Sig. Arrighetti, who was in splendid form. Sig. Lucenti was, as ever, delightful all through. Sig. Battani is most disappointing this year to many of those who delighted in him during the summer : but I confess I cannot agree with them alto­gether. He has not the exquisite delicacy which made certain songs so memorable, but it seems to me that his voice is far fuller and more developed, especially in the low notes. It may be simply the bad weather, or it may be that his voice is (if such things do happen !) in a state of transition from lyric to strong tenor. But the fact remains that he, Lucenti, and Arrighetti hold their own against the music and that the conductor has not to be always thinking whether a big orchestral effect will drown his voice. It is a pity his acting is so poor. His manipulation of the dagger (and, indeed, all the death scene) was rather absurd.

div.head: "FEDORA."
div.p: "Fedora" halted at first, but improved rapidly, and, taken altogether, was a fine performance. Sig. Orbellini was distinctly ex­cellent, as was Sig. Mastropasqau, who acted delightfully. Sig. Tschierdo sang the part of Loris really well. Sig. de Padova is a moat useful if rather light baritone. The "Chopin" scene was better done than is usually the case ; the pianist is not often a success, but he certainly was quite good in this case. Sig. Campanini is certainly a fine conductor, he knows his mario thoroughly, and has a thorough grasp of orchestra, chorus, and prin­cipals as well. They all have to do their utmost for him ; it was absolutely fascinating at times to watch his "bàson" and his hands and to notice how instantaneous was the response. It seemed impossible for his "per­sonnel'' to go wrong. We saw this in "Mefis- tofele" and ' Faust," and it was most marked in "Fedora." It is the height of pleasure to see such thorough mastery and knowledge combined.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Our Assouan Correspondent telegraphs that Lord and Lady Cromer arrived there by steamer on Saturday evening and left again thia morning. No receptions were held.
The family of the late Simon Arbib Bey beg to thank all their friends and acquaintances for the numerous tokens of sympathy which they have received in consequence of their recent bereavement.
Mrs. J. Hubbalday Barton has been safely delivered of a son. Mother and child are both doing well.

PROSPECTUS.
Thia Company has been formed for the purposes specified in the Memorandum of Association, and in particular:—
(1) To acquire and take over the business now carried on by Messrs. V. Levi & Co. of stock and produce brokers.
(2) To effect the purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the local and continental bourses and the London Stock Exchange for their own account and for the account of-third persons
To undertake the purchase and sale of cotton, cotton seed and other produce on the local and continental bourses and in England for their own account and for the account of third persons.

To undertake every kind of financial and commercial operation, including advances on Stock Exchange securities and upon cotton and co-ton seed and other merchandise, carrying over securities, arbitrations, discount and other commission business.

The arrangements made for the formation and promotion of the Company are embodied in preliminary agreement dated 22nd December 1906 and made between Moise Tilche Fils, B. Agaion Fils. 8. Tilche & Figii, Clement Castro, Constantin Pringo, Kamel Bey Teymur and V. Levi & Co. The subscribers to this agreement have agreed to subscribe and underwrite the whole of the issue of sharer to the public constituting one third of the total issue. The remaining two-thirds of the issue will be taken up by the subscribers to the agreement in the proportions shown below, and 1850 of the Deferred Shared will be allotted to them, also shown below, both Ordinary and Deferred Shares being subscribed tor wholly in cash :

The firm of V. Levi and Co., in consideration of their transferring the goodwill of their business to the Company, will under the above agreement have the right to take up 2,000 of the Deferred Shares on paying for them in cash The remaining 750 D ferred shares will be allotted equally amongst the five Director, who will pay for them in cash.

The above agreement also contemplates the appointment of M. Victor Levi as Managing Director (Administrateur delegue, of the Company, on a salary of £1000 per annum and a commission of 3 1/2 % on the net profits before any division thereof; and also the appointment of Mr. Neno Levi Mortera as Manager (Directeur) on a salary of £1000 per annum and a commission of 1 1/2 % on the same profits. These appointments will hold good for 5 years.

The Directors are interested in the promotion of the Company to the extent set ont above and as shown in the agreement above referred to, which contains all the arrange­ments made in contemplation of the formation of the Company.

The provisions of the Memorandum and Articles of Association with regard to the position of the shareholders, the division of profits, the creation of a Reserve Fund, and the remuneration of the Directors, are as follows —

From and out of the profits which in respect of each year shall, after deduction of any share attributed to the Managing Director or Manager of the Company, be available for dividens, a sum equal to 10% of such profits shall be carried to a special Reserve Funds; the remaining 90 % of such profits shall be dealt with as follows:—

(1) The holders of the Ordinary Shares will take fixed preferential Dividend not exceeding the rate of 6 % p.a. o i the Capital lor the time being paid up or cre­dited as being paid up thereon respectively, such Dividend to be paid as regards each year out of the profits of such year and to be non-cumulative.

(2) Of the surplus profits remaining after payment of this fixed preferential dividend, 7 % will be allotted to the Board of Directors, as remuneration for their services, such remuneration to be divided among tbe Directors in such proportion and manner as they themselves may determine, and in default of such determination then amongst them equally.

(3)The balance remaining of the surplus profits after providing for the above mentioned Reserve Fund, Preferential Dividend and remuneration of the Directors, shall be divided as to 60% among the holders of the Ordinary Shares rateably and in proportion to the number of Ordinary Shares held by them respectively, and as
The holders of the Ordinary Shares are entitled to priority as to return of capital and payment of dividend, whether declared or not, up to the commencement of the winding up.
In addition to the aforesaid remuneration, each Director shall also receive such further sum (if any) as the Company, in General Meeting may from time to time determine.

Any Director may be employed by or hold office of profit under the Company except that of Auditor of the Company, and may sot either personally or as a member of the firm for, or render any professional service to the Company, and may receive remuneration from the Company for so doing in addition to any remuneration payable to him as a Director. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra services or to make any special exertions in going or residing abroad, or in negotiating or carrying into effect any contract or arrangement by the Company or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, or to act as trustee for the Company or its debenture holders, and shall do so, the Company may remunerate such Director either by a fixed sum or percentage of profits or otherwise, as may' be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to, or in substitution for bis remuneration above provided. If any Director shall be appointed to represent the Company as a Director of any subsidiary or other company in which the Company shall he interested, he shall, unless otherwise agreed, be entitled to retain the remuneration attaching to such Directorship for his own muse.
The qualification of a director is the holding of 500 ordinary shares. The Company in General Meeting may increase or reduce the number of Directors.
No promotion money will be paid.

The preliminary expenses of and incidental to the formation of the Company down to end including allotment, including registration fees and stamp duty, legal expenses the scat of advertising and issuing this prospectus but excluding stamp duty on share warrants, will be paid by the Company, and are estimated at £3,000.

Application for shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's bankers, the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, Alexandria. If no allotment is made, the application money will be returned in full, and where, the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the applicant.
The Directors reserve to themselves discretion in the allotment of shares. Failure to pay an instalment oh shares when due will render previous payments liable to be forfeited.

The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at 10% of the shares offered. The whole of the preseat issue of shares has, however, as stated above, been subscribed and underwritten.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon.

The above mentioned contracts or copies of these documents, together with the print of the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association, may be inspected at the offices of Messrs V. Levi & Co Alexandria, and at the offices of the legal adviser to the Company at Alexandria.
Copies of this prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the same offices and at the offices of the Bankers of the Company at Alexandria.
Dated 14th February 1907. 29585 )

div.head: Egyptian Salt & Soda Coy., Ltd.
div.p: The Directors of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, Ltd , have decided to issue at par 50,000 new ordinary shares of £1 (one pound sterling) each to rank pari passa with existing ordinary shares. The new shares are now offered by preference to Holders of the 450,000 existing ordinary shares, and will be allotted to applicants in the proportion of one new share for every complete nine old shares. Forms of application can be obtained from the Com­pany's Bankers, the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo, Alexandria or London.

Holders of share warrants to bearer wishing to exercise their right to subscribe must present their warrants to the Company's Bankers for , verification and stamping from the 18th to 20th February 1907 together with applications for the new shares and the sum of 10/ (ten shil­lings) per share applied for. The balance of 10/- (ten shillings) per share most be paid on or before 20th March 1907. Share Warrants to bearer will be issued to Allottees in respect of tally-paid shares upon application, and payment of stamp duties.
Registered Share Holders should make appli­cation direct to the Secretary at the Registered Office of the Company, 6 Old Jewry, London, EC.

Applications for new shared must be received by the Company's Bankers or by the Company itself, as the case may be, not later than 20th February 1907, after which date the Directors will allot any new shares not applied for, to such persons as they may deem fit, 2953796

div.head: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Samedi 16 Février 1907.

Le taux de l'escompte libre A Londres se maintient à 4 3/4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a rétrogradé hier de 1/8 A a7. L'Unifiée est restée invariée A 102 3/4. La National Bank a perdu 1/8 A 28 1/4. L'Agricole est demeurée inchagee A 10, de même que la Daira A 17 1/2. La Delta Light a gagné 1/8 A 11 7/8
À Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien et la Banque d'Athenes ont cloture a leurs prix precedents, soit 775 et 135. Les Lots turcs ont avancé de 3 francs A 155.

Ici, la séance de ce matin a été plutôt calme mais la tenue générale du marché a été in­contestablement meilleure qu'hier. Eu outre, la côture a été marquée par de l'anima­tion et de la fermeté, ce qui est d'un bon augure et fait espérer une reprise. Aussi est-il regrettable qu'on nous réserve, pour la semaine prochaine encore, une série d'é­missions dont les effets pourraient bien entraver tontes les bonnes dispositions pos­sibles. On ne saurait vraiment trop engager les promoteurs de nouvelles entreprises A mo­dérer leur ardeur, A endiguer le flot impétu­eux de leurs appels de fonds, de facon A ne nuire ni aux antres, ni surtout A eux-mêmes. Certes, le soleil luit pour tout le monde et il y a de la place pour tous; mais encore est-il prudent da ne pas bourrer A outrance le mar-che égyptien, qui souffre deja visiblement d'une indigestion de titres don l'écoulement semble requérir des drastiques violents. * Fes­tin» lente." On ne perd rien pour attendre, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de bonnes affaires; l'es­sentiel est de les espacer et de les produire à des moments opportuns et favorables.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na­tional a clôturé A son prix précédent, soit 28 1/16-1/8, de même que l'Agricole A 9 7/8. Les parts de fondateur du Comptoir Financier, fractionnées en dix Ames, ont été traitées A £ 9.

Le Crédit Fonder a rétrogradé A .721 et son obligation A lots 1886 A 343.La D.ira est restée immobile A 17 6/16-3/8. L'Agrioole du Nil est remontée A 255: par contre, sa part a faibli A 7 5/16. La Nile Land est revenue A 22 5/8 et le Wardan A 7 1/2-9/16. L'Union Foncière s'est tassée A 6 1/4.. L'Allotment s'est encore alour­di A 3 1/4-5/16; sa part a cloture a 125.

Les Entreprises Immobilères et Travaux ont regagné une livre A 10; en bonne demande, leur part a avancé A P.E. 225. L'Epargne Im­mobilière a été ramenée A 3 1/8; sa part a terminé A* 2 2, après avoir fléchi A 190; ce sont la des cours transitoires appelés assurément a attirer l'attention des acheteurs.

L'Express Nile a été l'objet de fluctuations qui l'ont portée de 6 1/4 A 6 5/8 eu attendant mieux par suite des gros avantages offerts par la nouvelle émission fixée au 20 da courant; sa part a avancé A 330. L'Anglo-American Nile fléchi A 5 3/8-7/16, les Ciments A 53 et' la Brasserie des Pyramides à 126.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont haussé jusqu'A 30 1/8 pour terminer A 29 3/4. Les Upper Egypt ont avancé A 4 13/16-7/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est raffermie A 4 1/4. Les Markets sont remontés a 30 sh.

Dana la séance qu'elle a tenue hier soir l'as­semblée générale da la Corporation des Agents de change du Caire a continué de s'occuper des modifications très importantes proposées dans les statuts de la Corporation.

L'assemblée a passé ensuite A l'élection du nouveau Comité. M.M. H. Boutigny, E.C. Hogg, D. K. Raid et Henri de Vries ont déclaré formellement, qu'ils déliraient ne pas faire partie du nouveau Comité et ont, par consé­quent, prié les membres de ne pas porter leurs voix ear leurs noms.
Après quoi, l'assemblée a procédé A l'élec­tion da nouveau Comité, dont on trouvera la composition dans les journaux.

La Conseil d'administration de la Delta Land and Investment Co. a tenu aujourd'hui une réunion pour approuver les résolutions prises par le Board de la Delta Light Railways Co., relatives A la composition du Board local de la première de ces deux Sociétés et A diverses autres questions.

Nous croyons savoir que MM. P. Carver, Maurice Cattani Bey et le capitaine Adams ont été nommés en remplacement des adminis­trateurs de Londres, qui se sont décidés A se retirer. Ces Messieurs formeront le conseil de la Delta Land avec le baron Jacques de Menasce et M. J. W. Williamson. Un membre de la maison Suares leur sera adjoint dès que certaines négociations en cours entre cette maison et la Société auront définitivement abouti.

On annonce (officieusement dans les journaux qu'une assemblée générale extraordinaire de la George Nungovich Hotels sera convoquee poor le 4 mars prochain afin de ratifier la vente du Savoy Hotel et de donner éventuelle­ment les pouvoirs nécessaires au conseil d'ad­ministration pour vendre le Grand Continental
ou tons autres immeubles de la société.
Carnet de l'actionnaire :

Les actionnaires de la North Egypt Land Co. n'apprendront pas sans intérêt qu'aux termes d'an avis en date du 11 Février courant, putlié avant hier et hier par les jour­naux da Caire et d Alexandrie, le conseil d'ad­ministration de cette Sociéte a décidé que,

tons les appels de fonds précédents doivent être payés avant le 20 Février 1907 et que si l'on manque aa paiement avant la dite date, tontes les actions qui ne seront ainsi immé­diatement payées seront confisquées.

ACCORDING to the Company's Memorandum of Association the profits of the Company for each financial year which shall remain after setting aside a sum equal to 5 per cent of the' value of the Company's plant, or such larger amount as the Company may think necessary for providing for the renewal and augmentation of the Company's plant shall, subject as hereinaf er provided, be applicable as follows.
First.— To the payment of a cumulative preferential dividend at the rate of 6 per cent per annum on the capital for the time being paid up on the ordinary abates to the close of such year.
Secondly— Five per cent, thereof shall be carried to the Company's general reserve fund.

Thirdly— Of the residue of such balance two per cent shall be paid to the Chairman and 8 per cent shall be divided between the other Directors as and by way of additional remuneration for their services.

Fourthly.— Of the surplus of such residue 60 per cent shall be applicable to the payment of for the dividend on the Ordinary shares in proportion to the Capital l paid up thereon, and 4 per cent shall be applicable to the payment of dividend on the Founder's shares in proportion to the Capital paid up thereon.
In a winding up of the Company the Assets distributable amongst the Members shall be applied.
First.— In paying off the Capital paid up on the Ordinary Shares and all arrears of the cumulative dividend thereon, whether declared or not op tu the commencement of the winding up.

Secondly. —Of the balance 60 per cent shall be distributed amongst the holders of the Ordinary <!-- Unclear --> by them respectively and the other 40 percent shall be distributed amongst the holders of the <!-- Unclear --> shares in proportion to the Founder's shares held by them respectively
A copy of the Company's Memorandum of Association is endorsed on and forms part of this prospectas.
8,300 Ordinary Shares are now offered for subscription at par :
and the balance in three instalments of Lst. 1. each a from each other.

Each subscriber who receives an allotment of Ordinary Shares will have the right to subscribe at par for one Founder's Share in respect of every 10 of the said Ordinary Shares allotted to such subscriber.
Share Warrants to Bearer will be issued after full payment of the shares.

EMILIO MANUSARl, Advocate, Cairo.
OBJECTS. The Company has been formed for the purposes set forth in its Memorandum of Association and in particular
To acquire and takeover as a going concern the undertaking of the Nile Transport Company Cairo (constituted in Cairo in 1903 in accordance with Egypt an Law by G. Spetserpoulo andTh. N. Koressio-).

To carry on the business of proprietor of any kind of steamers and of freight carriers on the Nile and in the Egyptian Ports by means of barges stem boats, tugs etc., and to undertake all operations for the conveyance of passengers and goods tugging and towing vowels, loading and unloading of cargo by means of cranes or otherwise, repairing and building of all sorts of vessels and generally all other business in connection with navigation and carriage of goods.

According to agreements (below referred to) made the first in Loudon on the 1st day, of August 1906 and the second in Cairo on the 6th day of December 1906 both duly signed by all parties. The Nile Transport Company hereinafter designed as the Egyptian Company sells its business in general to the Nile Transport Company Limited hereinafter called the British Company, which purchases and acquires the goodwill of the said business with the right to use the name of the Nile Transport Company as part of the name of the British Company, all the lands, shipyards, warehouses, landing places, and property in general belonging to the Egyptian Company in Cairo, Alexandria, and elsewhere and all the floating mater ai, barges, tags, steamboats, stern wheels, etc., as well as the foil benefit of all pending contracts engagements and orders in connection with the paid business. Part of the consideration of the said sale is to be the sum of £23.000 which is to be paid by the British Company to the Egyptian Company as to £18,000 in cash within ten days after the date on which the Company shall be authorised to commence business and the balance of £5,000 within six months thereafter.

As further part of the said consideration the Egyptian Company is to be entitled to call for an allotment at par of 1,004 of the Founders shares in the Capital of the Company. The working material of the Egyptian Company has been inspected by Messrs. Harry Curtis, Director Engineer to the Government's Arsenal. Boulac, Mr. Gnido Maroni, Engineer. expert to the Mixed Court in Cairo, and J I s Debonne. Managing Director of the Society of Cemen's. Cairo, and their Official report says : "We the undersigned declare to have personally inspected and found that the actual "value of the foregoing plant, etc, according to detailed list, belonging to Messrs. "Spetseropoulo and Koressios, to the best of our knowledge and conscience is correct amounts to 22,819 Pounds Egyptian 65 milliemes. "
Signed: HARRY CURTIS
GUIDO MARONI.
J. DEBONNE.
CAIRO April the 15th 1906. .
To the Nile Transport Company. Cairo. .

"Referring to the valuation with which I have been entrusted together with Mr. Corti" "Direotor to the Government's Arsenal, of your fixed and floating material, I beg to declare in all sincerety that independently of the material itself valued by us, I gathered a totally favorable impiession of the whole of your plan and organisation.

I consider that your purchases have been made with best discretion and success "owing to the care and order obvions in all the details of your organisation. One can only "draw therefrom the elements of certain success for the future of your business.
. Yours truly
Signed : G. MARONI.
"I myself concur with all that Mr. Maroni has stated as to the above."
Signed: HARRY CURTIS.
To the Board of the Nile Transport Company, Cairo, . Gentlemen,

"In reply to your enquiry I have examined the whole of the property Messrs. Spetse- 'ropoulo & Koressios offer to your Society leaving to the experts appointed by you to establish * in detail the value of everything."
"Their work has been submitted to me and after examination I declare in all sincerity "that I find their estimation moat reasonable."
"This valuation being superior to that of the Vendors I consider that you can declare "yourselves in accordance with the price of L E. 22,500 (about Lst 23,076.18.6) they are 'asking."

"If you take into consideration that yon lave in hand a first-rate going concern, that "you are in possession of a new material most suitable to the needs of the country, Chat you 'have Warehouses and Landing Stages in Alexandria situated in a central commercial place "at the entrance of the Port and that you have well organised traffic and important offers for "carriage of goods, you will admit with me that the basinets proposed to you is called to a 'brillant future and that its intrinsical value is far superior to that resulting from a single "inventory."

"As soon as yon have united in Cairo your Workshop and Warehouse in one large "place on the bank of the Nile and you are able to employ the fleet you intend to build "you will find yourselves in a condition enabling you to oppose successfully any competition.''
In witness whereof I have signed this report,
Signed: J. DEBONNE.
Technical Director to the Society of Cement in Egypt, Cairo.

Messrs Georges Spetseropoulo & Theodore N. Koressios are to be two of the first Directors of the Company, and it is to be no objection to the agreement that the Founders being promoters and first Directors stand in a filuciary position towards the Company or that in the circumstances they do not constitute an independent Board and every member of the Company present and future is to be deemed to join the Company on this basis.
CONTRACTS. The following contracts have been made.

list.item: Contract dated the 1st August 1903 between the Nile Transport Company constituted in Cairo as above mentioned of the first part, His Excellency Joseph Gabriel Chakour Pasha, Charles J. Nicole, Emilio Manusardi, Georges Spetseropoulo, Walter Ablitt, Victor Coronel, Georges Miniakis and Theodore Nicolas Coresy Koressios (in this respect sometimes referred to as "the founders") of the second part and Neghib Ayoub on behalf of the Nile Transport Company Limited then in contemplation of the third part.
Contract dated the 6th day of December 1906 between the Nile Transport Company constituted in Egypt as aforesaid of the first part and the Nile Company Limited above men­tioned of the other part.

div.p: Beyond the Lst. 23,000 to be paid for the purchase of the material the British Company birds itself towards the Egyptian Company and undertakes to carry from Abouzabel to Alexandria at such times in each year as shall be convenient to the British Company and as shall be determined by its Board of Directors and for a period of 15 years from the 30th April 1902 twelve to twenty thousand cubic metres per annum of road metal (caillasse) which is to be supplied to the Municipality of Alexandria as per contract dated the 24th February 1903 between the said Theodora N. Coressy Koressios and la Société Buccianti Alam & Co. whereby the latter transfer to Mr. Th N. Koressios the conveyance of all the quantity of road metal to be carried to Alexandria viz, 12 to 20,000 cubic metres per annum for a period of 15 years from the 30th April 1902.
The price to be paid by the Egyptian Company to the British Company for this conveyance is fixed at three shillings four pence (3/4) or sixteen Egyptian piastres and a half per cubic metre.
The loading in the barges is to be paid by the Egyptian Company and the unloading by the British Company and this for the whole duration of the contract.
PROJECTS. The Company proposes to build large warehouses and landing stages in Cairo, Alexandria and elsewhere in order to allow goods to be stored at moderate fees.

Furthermore the Company proposes t » establish a special service for express delivery of the merchandise at the destinee's depots by means of animal carts, motor cars etc. most to the convenience of the local trade.
Increase op Material. Orders for the increase of material of the Company have already been placed and others are to follow in a way to enable the Company to increase considerably its traffic.

Underwriting Arrangements. The amount fixed by the Articles of Association as the minimum subscription on which the Directors nay proceed to allotment is 10 per cent. of the shares offered for subscription.
The whole number of the Ordinary Shares of the Capital of the Company have been

The Founders are to accept in the aforesaid proportions an allotment of snob part of the 8,300 shares as shall not be subscribed within 28 days after issue ot this prospectus, and they shall immediately pay the par value of these Shares to the Company.
Qualification OF the Directors The qualification of every Director is to be the holding of shares or stock of the Company of the nominal value of Lst. 200.

Remuneration oF Directors. The Directors are to be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration tor their services the sum of Lst. 100 per annum each and an additional sum of Lst. 200 to the Chairman plus the percentage of profits in that behalf specified in the Company's Memorandum of Association and each farther sums as shall from time to time be determined by the Company in General Meeting and such percentage of profits and further sums (if any) shall be divided among them in such proportions and manner as the Directors by agreement may determine and in default of such determination equally.

The Articles of Association also provide that the remuneration of the Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors or by the Company in General Meeting and may be by way of salary or commission or part cipation on profits or by any or all of those modes and there is a farther provision to the effect that if any Director being willing shall be called upon to perform extra services or to make any special exertion in going or residing abroad or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate such Director either by a fixed sum or by a percentage of profits or otherwise as may be determined to the Directors and such remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution for his share in the remuneration above-provided.

PRELIMINARY EXPENSES The preliminary expenses of the Company including the cost of the agreements and the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company and the registration thereof, and all stamps fees and legal expenses and generally all the preliminary expenses whatsoever are estimated at Lat 1500 and will be paid by the Company.
Application fur shares should be made on he form accompanying this Prospectus and sent to the Bankers with the amount for the deposit.

Where no allotment is made the deposit will be returned in fall, and where the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for, the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments of the surplus (if any) retained to the applicant. If default is made in payment of any instalment, the installments paid already will be liable to forfeiture.

Copies of the above mentioned agreements and reports together with a print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company may be inspected at the office of the Solicitors of the Company and at the Company's office in Cairo at any time during busi-ness hours before the list of subscriptions is closed.
Prospectuses and forms of application can be obtained at the office of the Company in London and in Cairo and from the Company's Solicitors and from their brokers in London and Cairo.
Dated the 5th day of February 1907. 29588 1

div.p: 2,000 Ordinary Shares have been subscribed for by the Signatories to the Memorandum of Association
81,300 Ordinary Shares are reserved for subscription by the Directors and their friends. 3,332 Founders' Shares are reserved for subscription by the Signatories to the Memorandum
of Association who are Directors and their friends at the rate of one Founders' Share for every 25 of the above-mentioned 2,000 and 81,300 Ordinary Shares
(A similar right is given by thisProspectus to applicants for multiples of • 25 Ordinary Shares)

7,500 Founders' Share are reserved for subscription by the Directors and their friends, who have arranged for the subscription of the whole of the Capital of the Company The Memorandum and Articles of Association provide that the profits of the Company which it shall from time to time be determined to distribute in respect of any year or other period, shall be applied in order of priority and manner following, that is to say :—

FIRST, as to 5 percent, thereof to payment into the Company's reserve fund. Secondly, to the payment of a dividend at the rate of 6 per cent, per annum on the capital for the time being paid up on the Ordinary Shares.
Fourthly, the residue of such profits shall be divided as to 60 per cent thereof
among the holders of the ordinary Shares, and as to 40 per cent thereof among the holders of the Founders' Shares.

and that in the winding up of the Company the surplus assets which may be distributable among the Members, shall as to 60 per cent, thereof be divided amongst the holders of the Ordinary Shares, and as to the remaining 40 per cent, thereof, among the holders of the Founders' Shares.

p.hi: 41,700 of the Ordinary Shares and the remainder of the bounders' Shares, viz. 1,668, are now offered for Subscription in the following manner :

div.p: Allotments will only do made to applicants of multiples of 25 Ordinary Shares, each 25 Shares entitling the applicant to subscribe for one Founders' Share.
The Ordinary Shares are payable as follows : -
10s. per Share on Application ;
l0s. per Share on Allotment ;
£1 two months after Allotment ;
and the balance in Calls not exceeding £l per Share at intervals of not less thau two months from the date of the last preceding Call. . —
1st per Share being payment in full on the Founders' Shares) must be paid on Application.

The minimum subscription upon which the Company may proceed to allotment is fixed by the Articles ofAssociation at 10 percent, of the Shares offered to the public for subscription, but the Directors will proceed to allotment of the whole of the Capital of the Company, the subscription of which has been arranged
Subscribers may on payment in full on the Ordinary Shares allotted to them, receive, at their own cost, Share Warrants to bearer in respect of such allotment if desired.

The primary objects of the Company are to establish a bunk for discount, to make advances on securities or share* or to carry them over, and general banking purposes, to take securities for safe custody, to make issues of. Egyptian and other companies either on its own account or for others, and to carry on a general financial and trust business for investment of capital in Egypt and the Sudan.
It is acknowledged that a bank of this description will supply an important the
need of an institution such as this having often been proved.
MANAGEMENT,

The Directors have been connected with Egypt for many years, and they are confident that there 'an immense field available for remunerative trade and industry They look for a considerableexpansion of business relationships between Egypt and other countries, and having regard to the time and political situation and the period of prosperity through which Egypt is passing, they are of opinion that the present is propitious, and they anticipate a successful and remunerative career for this Company, and they have great reliance in the personality of the Manager, who is well known and esteemed in financial circles and whose business relationship and experience is sufficient to warrant a firm and intelligent management.

The Directors and their friends thoroughly believe in the future prosperity of the Company, and accordingly have arranged to themselves subscribe for 81,300 Ordinary Shares, and to take up the whole of this issue without commission.
The Articles of Association provide as follows :
The qualification of every Director shall be the holding of Shares or Share Warrants to Bearer of the Company of the nominal value of not less than £1,000.

That each of the Directors, other than the Chairman, shall be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration for his services, a salary at the rate of £100 per annum, and the Chairman shall be paid a salary at the rate of £200 per annum. The Directors shall also be entitled to the share of the profits under Clause 6 of the Memorandum of Association (mentioned on the first page of this Prospectus), and the same shall be divided among the Directors in such proportions and manner as they by agreement may determine, and in default of such Agreement equally.

If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to or shall perform any extra services, or shall make any special exertions in going or resiling out of the country where he usually resides or otherwise, or any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate the Director either a fixed sum or by percentage of profits or otherwise as may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to, or in substitution for his share in the remuneration above provided.

The Directors may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold office, and may, from time to time, remove or dismiss him or them from office, and appoint another or others in his or their place or places. The remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors or by the Company in General Meeting, and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits, or by any or all of those modes.

The estimated amount of the preliminary expenses connected with and incidental to the formation of the Company and the issue of this Prospectus, including Solicitors' charges, registration fees, advertising, printing, postages, office expenses, etc., is £4000.
There are no Contracta.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, with the names, addressee and descriptions of the signatories thereto, is printed in the fold, and forms part of this Prospectus.

It is intended to apply, in due course, for an official quotation and settlement of the above Shares on the London Stock Exchange. Applications for the Shares should be made on the accompanying forms, and sent together with the necessary deposit, to the Bankers of the Company, crossed to the account of the Company. If no allotment is made, the application money will be returned in full, and where the number of Shares allotted is lees than the number applied for, the surplus money paid on application will be credited towards the amount payable on allotment, and any balance will be returned. Failure to pay allotment money or any instalment on the Shares allotted at the times fixed will render the amount paid liable to forfeiture. Copies of the Memorandum and the Articles of Association can be inspected at the Cairo offices of the Company at any time during business hours whilst the list remains open. Dated 8th February, 1907. 29587-2-1

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations.
